title: 105_hr4539
content: The "Consular Review Act of 1998" establishes a Board of Visa Appeals under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of State establishes a Board of Visa Appeals within the Department of State composed of 5 members, with no more than 2 being consular officers. The Board has authority to review discretionary decisions of consular officers regarding immigrant and nonimmigrant visas, petitions, and waiver applications for inadmissibility grounds. The Board of Visa Appeals reviews waiver applications for inadmissibility grounds under section 212. The Board can overrule or remand decisions of consular officers if contrary to the evidence. Proceedings follow regulations consistent with the Act. The Secretary of State shall prescribe regulations for consular officers' decisions, including notice of review process and written record requirements. The consular officer must provide the Board with the record of proceeding within 30 days of receiving a request for review. The appellant will receive a notice of the review process. The appellant must be given notice of the Board proceedings, can choose their own counsel, and must request a review in writing within 60 days. The Board will review decisions upon request of the alien or interested parties. Upon request, interested parties include the petitioner or beneficiary of approved immigrant visa petitions, the petitioner of a nonimmigrant visa petition, and postsecondary educational institutions accepting nonimmigrant students. The section outlines different entities that can request a review of an alien's acceptance in a program, including recognized international agencies, treaty investors or traders, and organizations in the United States. There is a limitation on the number of reviews that can be requested in a 24-month period. This section is not meant to restrict any actions. The section allows various entities to request a review of an alien's program acceptance. It does not limit further administrative or judicial review. The Secretary of State will charge a fee for review requests to cover administration costs. The effective dates for the amendment are specified. The Board of Visa Appeals must be appointed within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Technical amendments are made to section 222(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
